newsitem.title: FRANCE: French stocks end lower in consolidation.
newsitem.headline: French stocks end lower in consolidation.

text.p: Profit-taking in the afternoon brought Fench shares to a softer close. Traders said a consolidation was natural after yesterday's rapid rise to giddy historic highs.
Traders cited various factors supporting the orderly retreat, including health worries for Russian president Boris Yeltsin and weakness on Wall Street and in U.S. Treasuries.
The blue-chip CAC-40 index closed down 14.16 points or 0.59 percent at 2,387.98. The CAC-40 futures contract was down at 2,391 from 2,406 on Tuesday's close.
Volume was a hefty nine billion francs.
* Axa retreats 2.17 percent to 341.9 francs, as market sources cite fears of an issue of new shares from early conversion of a convertible bond issued in 1993.
* Any new shares should not dilute earnings as the potential 14 million new shares should already be factored into analysts' earnings forecasts.
* Accor bucks the market, rising 0.62 percent to 651 francs, after Paribas Capital Markets upgrades the stock to neutral from sell, citing favourable currency moves.
* Lagardere gains 2.62 percent to 148.8. Analysts consider it undervalued, ripe investors looking for medium caps.

* Lagardere has lagged the sector and could benefit from a break up of its defence and communications activities, or the disposal of military interest. Such deals could be independent of whether it wins Thomson-CSF in the current privatisation effort.
* Canal Plus ended unchanged at 1,106 francs, after the broadcaster confirmed it signed an agreement on tuesday to take 52 percent in a Swiss company to manage the Servette Geneva soccer club.
* Synthelabo, Sanofi and Credit National fall to profit taking.
* Valeo ends up 3.03 percent at 370.9, helped by rumours of possible entry into the CAC index, replacing UAP, also talk of big General Motors contract.
* Havas falls after steep rises on speculation it might make a buy-out offer to minority shareholders in CEP Communications.
* SGS-Thomson adds 4.73 percent to 411.6, on the back of strong fourth-quarter profit growth for Intel.
